Award.AwardTitle: On the Geometry of Calabi-Yau Moduli and Kahler-Einstein manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1206748, Principal Investigator: Zhiqin Lu

The object of this proposal is to continue to study several fundamental problems in differential geometry and related fields. The long-term goal is to study the higher order BCOV conjecture and relations between the existence of Kahler-Einstein metrics and the stability of complex manifolds. One of the short-term goals is to study the different notations of stability. In particular, the proposer will study the relations between the Donaldson-Futaki invariant and the Tian-Futaki invariant. The proposer believes that, like the Futaki invariant, both invariants are combinatorial. He will also generalize the Tian-Yau-Zelditch expansion, study the gap problem, study the spectral problem of quantum layers, and study some fundamental linear algebra problems related to the mean curvature flow.

The proposed problems are important in differential geometry and mathematical physics. It has significant impacts in our understanding of the Universe. As before, he will convey his mathematical insights to students and to the general public by giving talks and advising students. He will continue to encourage more people, especially women and minorities, to study mathematics. To achieve the goal, the proposer is involved in many educational activities such as the California Math Counts, the UCI Anteater Math Club, the UCI School of Physical Sciences Mentor Program, etc. He is involved in the innovation of both undergraduate and graduate courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the past year, I have studied the Bergman kernel on Kahler manifold and the inverse problem of polygons. 

The Bergman kernel is one of the funamental objects in complex geometry, a branch of fast developing field of mathematics. Joint with Chiung-ju Liu, we studied some fundamental questions in the asymptotic expansion of the Bergman kernel. This piece of work is to appear in the Transcation of American Mathematics Society.

Joint with Julie Rowlett, we proved that for certain types of "acute" trapezoids, the shape of them are completely determined by their Dirichlet eigenvalues. This answers the famous question of Kacs: "Can one heat the shape of a drum?" in the acute trapzoid case. Contrast to the usual methods using in the inverse problems, we make use of both the heat kernel expansion and the wave kernel expansion in order to get more spectrum invariants. The result is new, but we decide to submit the paper to "The American Mathematics Monthly" which has a wider range of readers (The readers of the jouranl contains reseach mathmatians, college and high school teachers) . The paper has been accepted by the journal.

I have been continuing working on two fields: complex geometry and spectrum problems of the Laplcians. During the last three years, we have published 12 papers in journals and conference proceedings.
